awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Institutional Transformation at Florida International University
awd_abstract_narration:
The ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of women faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in areas such as policy, practice, culture, and organizational climate.  The ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (ADVANCE-IT) track supports the development of innovative organizational change strategies within an institution of higher education to enhance gender equity in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

Florida International University (FIU) is the 4th largest public university in the U.S. and the 2nd largest in Florida, with over 54,000 students with over 80% from underrepresented groups.  FIU's goal for this ADVANCE-IT project is to develop institutional structures, processes, and climate that builds an affirming and fair workplace.  There are four objectives within this project: (1) Address issues that impede the recruitment, retention, and promotion of women STEM faculty, particularly women of color, to better reflect the demographics of the FIU student body; (2) Educate faculty about biases and "microclimates" (the local social climates that positively or negatively impact the work experience of faculty within the institution); (3) Develop strategies and tools to help move faculty from insight to action to promote gender equity; (4) Develop the Advance Florida Network comprised of the Florida metropolitan research universities (FIU, University of Central Florida, and University of South Florida).   

The FIU project includes two social science research studies that will add to our knowledge of equity in STEM academics and strategies to foster equity.  The first study will increase our understanding of "microclimates" and the role of the majority faculty in setting the climate of a department.  The second study will investigate the long-term impact on the behavior of participants in the Deep Change Program intervention which includes training on inequity and using strategies to intervene.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The FIU Institutional Transformation ADVANCE grant aimed to bring about systemic change at Florida International University (FIU) by creating an inclusive and fair workplace for women faculty and faculty from underrepresented groups.

The project had four main goals:
1.    Recruitment and Advancement of Women in STEM:

  • Increase the representation of women faculty in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM), with a focus on underrepresented minority (URM) women.
  • Initiatives included training faculty search committees to recognize and mitigate biases, implementing a search advocate program to emphasize community responsibility for inclusive hiring practices, conducting workshops on equitable faculty evaluation, creating a salary equity program, and expanding the Faculty Mentoring Program.

2.    Educating Faculty about Gender and Ethnic Biases:

  • Provide leadership training for chairs and conduct a microclimate research project to understand how multiethnic cultural climates in STEM departments affected the recruitment and advancement of women, particularly Hispanic-American and African-American women.

3.    Bystander Intervention Program:

  • Move faculty from insight to action by implementing the Bystander Intervention Program, an evidence-based program to raise awareness and empower faculty to intervene in situations of bias. This included a nationally renowned theater program for educating faculty on issues of bias and harassment.

4.    Building Supportive Networks:

  • Develop the Advance Florida Network for women STEM faculty and postdoctoral fellows from FIU, University of Central Florida (UCF), and University of South Florida (USF).

Key Impacts

Recruitment, Retention, and Advancement

  • The percentage of tenured/tenure track (T/TT) women faculty in STEM increased from 18% to 22%.

  • Representation among assistant professors in Social and Behavioral Sciences (SBS) rose from 43% to 63%.

  • Training initiatives led to the expansion of resources for equitable search processes, with over 1,100 faculty participating in Best Practices for Hiring (STRIDE) workshops; 90% rated them as effective. 280 faculty have been trained as Search Advocates.

Faculty Mentoring and Leadership Development

  • The Faculty Mentor Program (FMP) improved mentoring and leadership development for faculty across all ranks and types of positions including tenure-line, research, clinical, and teaching faculty, with over 550 participants benefiting from deep learning opportunities. FIU faculty now report mentoring as a strength in Faculty Satisfaction (COACHE) surveys.
  • Leadership training was provided through the Women’s Faculty Leadership Institute Event and opportunities for faculty to lead diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) efforts as ADVANCE Faculty Fellows and College Equity Advisors.

Policy and Procedures Review

  • Six of eleven colleges and 48 departments developed plans to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion. Annual reports on progress were required to create awareness and demonstrate commitment to DEI efforts.

  • New and revised policies and procedures were implemented to enhance equity and transparency, including the mandatory Best Practices workshops for faculty search committee members and revisions to the Faculty Hiring Manual to incorporate evidence-based best practices to improve equitable hiring outcomes.

Salary Inequities Mitigation

  • Identified and mitigated salary inequities through 82 salary adjustments over the program's duration.

Social Science Research: Behavioral Intervention

  • Developed the Bystander Leadership Program (BLP) to raise awareness and provide skills to intervene in bias situations. It was developed, pilot tested and conducted as both a research project and as an educational program for STEM and SBS faculty. Over 600 faculty have attended BLP.

  • The BLP was successful in increasing awareness and confidence among faculty. At three months after the workshop, intervention group participants also reported that they took significantly more actions to intervene than did the comparison group.

  • Results from the project have been disseminated through publications and presentations, and the BLP program is being adopted by Georgia State University as part of their ADVANCE grant.

  • The FIU ADVANCE Theater Program, addressing bias and harassment, expanded independently and is available nationwide.

Building Supportive Networks

  • The ADVANCE Florida Network (AFN) provided cross-institutional mentoring, networking, and collaboration opportunities for 41 T/TT STEM women faculty and postdoctoral scholars among three universities. All reported being very satisfied with the program.

In summary, the FIU Institutional Transformation ADVANCE grant achieved its goals by influencing faculty recruitment, retention, and advancement, implementing effective mentoring and leadership programs, reviewing policies for diversity and inclusion, addressing salary inequities, and establishing supportive networks for women STEM faculty. However , the extent to which these programs will be institutionalized, i.e., made permanent, is currently unclear as they are being evaluated for compliance with recently-enacted legislation in Florida that prohibits University expenditures from any source on programs that support DEI efforts.
